image.altText: A photo of Giuliano and his daughter walking on a footpath, holding hands. Taken from behind.

props.synopsis: A Perth gym where bodybuilder Giuliano Pirone collapsed in a shower and went undiscovered for 15 hours before later dying in hospital is being investigated by WorkSafe WA.

title.children: Safety watchdog to investigate Perth gym after bodybuilder collapsed in shower, spent 15 hours undetected

image.altText: Exterior of the District Court of Western Australia on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: A Kimberley man has been sentenced to five years behind bars after he distributed and possessed child abuse material. Police found more than 20,000 images of children being exploited on one of his devices.

title.children: Five year jail term for man who shared 'depraved' footage of children online

image.altText: Signage on the side of the Central Law Courts building in Perth during the daytime.

props.synopsis: A coroner rejects a bid by one of WA's highest ranking justice bosses to remove himself from an inquest into the state's first death in youth detention.

title.children: Coroner rejects bid by high-ranking justice boss to step down from youth detention death inquest

image.altText: Wine being put in a glass

props.synopsis: In the first visit by Chinese delegates since trade tariffs were lifted in April, West Australian wineries are showcasing their premium wines to big buyers in the hopes of landing lucrative contracts.

title.children: WA wineries plan to deal with China differently since tariffs lifted in April

image.altText: Smoke billows over a skyline

props.synopsis: The Israeli military says it launched a wave of artillery and air strikes on Hamas infrastructure in Gaza and Beirut's south to thwart what it said was an imminent attack. Follow live.

title.children: Fighting intensifies between Israel and Iran-backed militia on October 7 anniversary, with fresh strikes in Beirut and Gaza

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Sirens sounded in central Israel after Hamas and Hezbollah launch rockets
Israeli PM vows 'we will not stop' in October 7 address
ABC correspondents describe mood on the ground

image.altText: The Israeli flag hanging from the frame of a house.

props.synopsis: One year ago, Hamas militants infiltrated Be'eri kibbutz. It was one of many coordinated attacks across Israel that began the Israel-Hamas war — and a delayed response by the Israeli defence force has been blamed for some of the 101 deaths, and dozens taken hostage.

title.children: Hundreds dead, no answers. These Israelis want to know why the IDF failed them

image.altText: A woman walks amid rubble with her young daughter in hand, who's wearing a red dress.

props.synopsis: On October 7, 2023, Palestinians in Gaza were doing normal, everyday things, until their lives quickly turned upside down. One year later, we take a look at what happened inside Gaza through the lived experience of two Palestinians.

title.children: The war in Gaza has raged for a whole year. This is what it has been like for those who lived through it

image.altText: The flags of Iran and the United States of America behind a petrol pump.

props.synopsis: A day after oil prices surged, US President Joe Biden warned Israel against military strikes on Iran's oil export facilities for good reason — any attack could ignite another bout of inflation, and possibly plunge the world into recession.

title.children: How the Middle East could derail the global economy

image.altText: Jack Darling kicks a goal

props.synopsis: West Coast sends veteran forward Jack Darling to North Melbourne for a fourth-round draft pick, as unrestricted free agent Jack Graham tells the Tigers he is heading west to join the Eagles. Here's all the action from day one of the AFL trade period.

title.children: Eagles trade Jack Darling to Kangaroos, set to add Jack Graham from Richmond

image.altText: Rows of milk cartons lined up in a shop fridge

props.synopsis: There is currently no law requiring grocery stores to display visible pricing on their shelves, creating a legal loophole that leaves some shoppers "flying blind" when it comes to the weekly shop.

title.children: 'There would be outrage': Shoppers confused and frustrated by shops with no prices

image.altText: Close up of some table salt on the palm of someone's hand.

props.synopsis: Salt is one of the most versatile resources in the world, and now that Australia's biggest solar salt farm is operational, it is expected to produce millions more tonnes each year.

title.children: Why does the world need so much salt? The answer is in almost everything you touch

image.altText: Yvonne Stretton sits with Dr Kean-Seng Lim in his office.

props.synopsis: Data from the Royal Australian College of GPs shows doctors are spending longer with patients but are worried about their financial viability as more patients either delay or avoid making appointments.

title.children: Good GPs are 'invisible' but this doctor uses maths to measure success

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek holds a python at Parliament House

props.synopsis: Shortly after starting as minister, Tanya Plibersek laid out a plan to put the environment back on the national agenda. Two years on, as Australia hosts a global summit, Michael Slezak looks at how things have gone.

title.children: She said Australians 'voted for the environment' in 2022. Two years on, what's Tanya Plibersek been able to achieve?

image.altText: Banking apps appear on a phone screen

props.synopsis: Consumer groups are calling on the government to abandon parts of new draft scam laws, saying they are unworkable and put the onus of proof on victims seeking compensation.

title.children: Growing backlash over new draft scam laws as consumer groups unite to condemn government victim compo proposal

image.altText: AntonioMichell-4

props.synopsis: Antonio was a specialist trauma physio in Chile. In Australia, he has swept floors and driven rideshare for years waiting for recognition, despite a physio shortage.

title.children: 'We have doctors driving rideshare': Government urged to streamline overseas qualification schemes

image.altText: Kangaroo threatened by bushfire

props.synopsis: The group warns climate change will cause more regular and severe natural disasters that will overwhelm the ability of the federal government and its agencies to help protect and rebuild communities.

title.children: 'Unimaginable new extremes': Call for 'emergency mobilisation' to deal with climate change threats

image.altText: Christos Tsiolkas crosses his arms and stands at a pool in front of signage declaring "deep water".

props.synopsis: Christos Tsiolkas is one of Australia's most celebrated authors, but as a young man he nearly left the country after experiencing 'absolute euphoria' overseas.

title.children: 'I was wrong': The piece of writing that author Christos Tsiolkas regrets to this day

image.altText: Liam and Noel Gallagher of Oasis pose in jackets in front of a beige backdrop.

props.synopsis: The British band announce Sydney and Melbourne dates, marking first Australian tour since 2005.

title.children: Oasis announce Australian tour dates – and no dynamic pricing

image.altText: A wire fence surrounds the yard at an immigration detention centre.

props.synopsis: More asylum seekers could be released and financially compensated if a newly launched class action on behalf of South Sudanese refugees succeeds.

title.children: Fresh test for immigration system amid push to release and compensate more asylum seekers

image.altText: A glass office building exterior reflects other buildings.

props.synopsis: "They got away with it" is a common refrain after corporate scandals that end without consequences for individuals. A landmark High Court ruling could radically reshape that.

title.children: The court decision sending a chill through board rooms and executive suites

image.altText: A young woman smiling broadly and hugging another woman.

props.synopsis: There have been tears of joy and relief as hundreds of Australians evacuated from Lebanon touched down in Sydney on the first of two government-assisted repatriation flights.

title.children: Tears of joy and relief as hundreds of Australians fleeing conflict in Lebanon touch down in Sydney

image.altText: A blurry image of a boat sinking

props.synopsis: A Samoan man said oil from the sunk HMNZS Manawanui was identifiable along the coast for several kilometres which would have a "massive impact".

title.children: Fears of 'crazy' environmental impact after NZ naval ship sinks off Samoa's south

image.altText: Two men pick up award on stage

props.synopsis: The winners for medicine are selected by the Nobel Assembly of Sweden's Karolinska Institute medical university and receive a prize sum of $1.6 million.

title.children: US duo Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun win Nobel Prize in Medicine

image.altText: GettyImages-2177293524

props.synopsis: England secures a comfortable seven-wicket win over South Africa to move them a step closer to taking out the women's T20 World Cup.

title.children: England a step closer to T20 glory as South Africa counts the cost of dropped catches

image.altText: The aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt departs Naval Base Guam

props.synopsis: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba wants an end to his country's "asymmetrical" security relationship with the United States.

title.children: Japan's new prime minister proposes base in Guam, where locals celebrate liberation from Japan

image.altText: gopro footage of a person walking over a deep pit

props.synopsis: An experimental study asked 21 people to watch short videos relating to three situations. Here's what the researchers found.

title.children: Spiders, heights, and social situations — not all fears are created equal, study suggests

image.altText: Close up photo of man with grey hair smiling

props.synopsis: A 27-year-old man has appeared in a Perth court charged with murdering his father at a regional roadhouse.

title.children: 'An amazing man': Tributes flow for man allegedly killed by son at Salmon Gums roadhouse

image.altText: A woman reaches out to an alarm clock from bed.

props.synopsis: If you work with people in different parts of the country, the first week of daylight saving can cause all sorts of headaches.

title.children: How to work effectively across time zones during daylight saving

image.altText: Partly smiling older woman with shaggy brown hair cut short, wears black and white striped tee and a necklace around her neck

props.synopsis: With its picturesque canals and waterfront homes, the Victorian holiday haven of Paynesville appears immune to the poverty that is quietly gripping the nation. But Foodbank Victoria says the reality is much harsher than it looks.

title.children: Hunger relief charity struggles as food insecurity becomes a 'disaster behind closed doors'

image.altText: Giant screen on the wall of the ASX, with large red numbers, showing the price of shares which have fallen.

props.synopsis: US stocks tumble into the red, while oil prices rise on Middle East conflict fears. Local stocks are tipped to dip at the open. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street loses 1 per cent, ASX to dip

image.altText: A large crowd holding signs and waving jewsih flags work through a Melbourne street.

props.synopsis: In cities across the country, candles are being lit to mark one year since the Hamas terror attack on October 7, and the subsequent months of war in Gaza.

title.children: One year on from the October 7 attack, communities across Australia are pausing to remember those who have been lost

image.altText: Bill Bailey stands with one hand raised, the other over his heart, singing joyfully in front of bank of keyboards

props.synopsis: One song reminds British comic Bill Bailey of a dear, departed friend. And the other he wants to be played at his funeral.

title.children: How Talking Heads and Johnny Cash help Bill Bailey laugh in the face of death
